title: Shingles vaccine: Why have it and what are the side effects?
author: Jamie Eske
description: The shingles vaccine is effective, but it can cause side effects. Here, learn about the vaccine, its side effects, who may benefit, and who should avoid it.
cleaned_text: The Shingrix vaccine can help prevent shingles, but it can have some side effects, including swelling at the injection site, short-term tiredness, and stomach pain. Shingles, or herpes zoster, is an infection caused by the chicken pox virus, Varicella zoster. Adults who had [chicken pox](/articles/239450.php) as children carry the dormant virus. The virus can reactivate to cause [shingles](/articles/154912.php) in later life, but the vaccine can prevent this. However, some people have concerns about potential dangers and whether shingles vaccines are effective. One vaccine currently has [Food and Drug Administration (FDA)](https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/shingrix) [Shingrix](/articles/326241)). Previously, a different zoster virus vaccine (Zostavax) was available. However, it has been discontinued. This article provides information about the Shingrix vaccine and its possible adverse effects. A shingles vaccination can significantly reduce the risk of developing shingles and related complications, including [postherpetic neuralgia (PHN)](/articles/160253.php), a common complication that involves [long-term](https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/shingles) Other complications of shingles can include: - Eye complications. Having [shingles in or around the eye](/articles/322870.php)increases the risk of corneal ulcers, [glaucoma](/articles/9710.php), retinal necrosis, and partial or total vision loss. - Pneumonia. The shingles virus can spread to the internal organs, resulting in [internal shingles](/articles/321217.php). People can also develop [pneumonia](/articles/151632.php)if the virus infects the lungs. - Encephalitis. If the shingles virus infects the brain, it can cause severe, life threatening [inflammation](/articles/248423.php). [Encephalitis](/articles/168997.php), or brain inflammation, can cause memory problems, loss of some motor functions, mood changes, [epilepsy](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/8947.php), and even death. Pneumonia and encephalitis are rare complications of shingles. A shingles vaccine [may cause](https://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/drugInfo.cfm?setid=0280849d-5c78-4a9d-8941-4eab429f6bd8) the following short-term side effects: - redness, swelling, or itching near the injection site [tiredness](/articles/248002.php)or fatigue [headache](/articles/73936.php) [muscle aches and pains](/articles/322869) - gastrointestinal symptoms [fever](/articles/168266)and shivering According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html#side-effects) In rare cases, a person may experience a severe allergic reaction — or [anaphylaxis](/articles/216062.php) — after a shingles vaccination. The CDC notes that only [one or two](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html#side-effects) Signs of a severe allergic reaction [include](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6156836/) - low [blood pressure](/articles/270644.php) - dizziness or lightheadedness [hives](/articles/157260.php) - stomach pain - vomiting [anxiety](/info/anxiety/) - breathing problems or [wheezing](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/321736.php) - swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or uvula, which is a part of the throat If a person suspects that they or someone nearby is experiencing anaphylaxis, they should seek emergency medical aid. Anyone in the U.S. who has experienced a severe allergic reaction to the shingles vaccine can report this [online](https://vaers.hhs.gov/) using the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System or by calling 1-800-822-7967. Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that can be life threatening. The symptoms develop suddenly and include: - hives - swelling of the face or mouth - wheezing - fast, shallow breathing - a fast heart rate - clammy skin - anxiety or confusion - dizziness - vomiting - blue or white lips - fainting or loss of consciousness If someone has these symptoms: - Check whether they are carrying an epinephrine pen. If they are, follow the instructions on the side of the pen to use it. - Dial 911 or the number of the nearest emergency department. - Lay the person down from a standing position. If they have vomited, turn them onto their side. - Stay with them until the emergency services arrive. Some people may need more than one epinephrine injection. If the symptoms do not improve in 5-15 minutes, or they come back, use a second pen if the person has one. Shingrix is the only shingles vaccine that currently has approval from the [FDA](https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/shingrix) According to the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/shingles/downloads/shingles-factsheet-adults.pdf) A person will have the Shingrix vaccine in two doses. The [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/mm6703a5.htm) With some exceptions, adults [over 50](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) According to the CDC, research has shown that Shingrix is safe. Some people experience short-term adverse effects, such as a fever, muscle aches, and headaches. However, these usually last only [2-3 days](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) In rare cases, people have developed Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) after having the shingles vaccine. However, this can also happen after shingles. GBS is a severe nervous system disorder. The [FDA](https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/shingrix) It can happen with the following: - a medical condition that compromises the immune system, such as [AIDS](/articles/17131.php) [cancer](/info/cancer-oncology/)that affects the lymphatic system or [bone marrow](/articles/285666.php) - cancer treatments, such as radiation or [chemotherapy](/articles/158401.php) - medications that affect the immune system, such as steroids However, a person with a weakened immune system should speak with their doctor about whether to have the vaccine and when. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/shingles/surveillance.html) [10-18%](https://www.cdc.gov/shingles/surveillance.html) Older adults and people with weakened immune systems have a higher risk of developing shingles, according to the [National Institutes of Health (NIH)](https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/shingles#how) The [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html#who-should-get-shingrix) [FDA](https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/zostavax-herpes-zoster-vaccine-questions-and-answers) Adults should also have a shingles vaccine if they: - do not remember if they have had chicken pox - do not remember if they have ever had a shingles vaccine - have already received the Zostavax vaccine, now discontinued - have a history of shingles The CDC now recommends the shingles vaccine for younger adults [aged 19 and over](https://www.cdc.gov/shingles/vaccination/immunocompromised-adults.html) A person [should not have](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) - during pregnancy - if they currently have shingles - if they have previously had a severe allergic reaction to any of the ingredients in the vaccine - in some cases, if they have a weakened immune system A doctor can advise an individual on having the Shingrix vaccine. People who test negative for the Varicella zoster virus can get the chicken pox vaccine instead. Here are some questions people often ask about shingles immunization. Which is better, Shingrix or Zostavax? Zostavax was discontinued in [November 2020](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/zostavax/index.html) [90%](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) How long does the shingles vaccine last? Immunity remains strong for at least [7 years](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) Does Medicare cover Shingrix? According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/public/shingrix/index.html) Medicare Part B does not cover the shingles vaccine. Medicaid and insurance may cover the cost of Shingrix. A person should check with their insurance provider to see if it is covered. The risk of shingles significantly increases with age.
